journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Integrated motion planning and trajectory control system for unmanned air vehicles

article-meta.aff: Center of Excellence for Aerospace Systems, Sharif University of Technology, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Seid H Pourtakdoust, Center of Excellence for Aerospace Systems, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran 11365 8639, Iran. Email: pourtak@sharif.edu

abstract.p: Motion planning and trajectory control are two basic challenges of unmanned vehicles. In motion planning problem, feasible trajectories are developed while nonlinear dynamic model and performance constraints of the vehicle under utility are considered. In this study, motion planning is performed via an enhanced particle swarm optimization algorithm. The resulting offline generated trajectories are tracked using a nonlinear trajectory control system methodology. The Lyapunov-based constrained backstepping approach and command filters are utilized in designing the trajectory control system. Command filters smoothen the input signals and provide their derivatives. Evaluation of the proposed integrated approach in several simulated scenarios has effectively demonstrated the potential of both algorithms in generating optimal contour matching trajectories as well as excellent tracking capability of the trajectory control system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Improvements in the level of autonomy of unmanned air vehicles (UAVs) are highly desirable and under pursuit by many researchers. Two important areas of enhancement in UAV autonomy are related to motion planning and trajectory control system (TCS).

Motion planning, in the context of autonomous vehicles, refers to the derivation of a plan to steer the vehicle from a point to the target location while avoiding obstacles. It is desirable to optimally generate such a plan using existing resources while minimizing certain cost functions. The key modeling aspects of motion planning are related to system dynamics and its corresponding dynamic constraints. Therefore, to perform the mission correctly, one needs to observe and utilize all maneuvering capabilities of the vehicle.

The behavioral model of a vehicle in flight can be described by a series of nonlinear differential equations. Adding the constraints of motion planning to the equations of motion will further complicate this set of equations. This level of complexity of the equations cannot be easily overcome by numerical optimization algorithms. Because of this fact, most of the trajectory planning schemes such as variation-based optimal control schemes,1 configuration space-based methods,2,3 and heuristic optimization methods4,5 have used simplified dynamic models of the vehicle or have simply used the kinematics equations. On the other hand, UAV dynamic constraints and performance limitations should be considered to ensure a practical trajectory.

To address these problems, the maneuver automaton (MA) idea, first proposed by Frazzoli,6–8 is utilized in this study. MA uses a series of deterministic inputs. These inputs include a set of trim states (TSs) and maneuver trajectories that transfer the vehicle from one TS to another. Thus, by generating a library of finite TSs and their corresponding transition maneuvers, the problem of motion planning turns into a hybrid optimization problem. This way, a practical trajectory is obtained by connecting the trim and maneuver trajectories in the realm of vehicle flight envelope.

Utilizing the MA concept and an ant colony optimization (ACO) algorithm, the problem of motion planning in the presence of deterministic threats has been investigated in the study of Krenzke.9 The objective to be minimized is the distance to the target and minimum exposure to the threats. The disadvantage of this study is that the maneuvers within the library have been formed using the kinematics equations. Additionally, only one constant time span has been assigned to all maneuvers, while in practice, different transition maneuvers may have different time spans, due to their initial and final conditions. In addition, the ACO algorithm is employed to solve the motion planning problem, which is a discrete optimization scheme. Therefore, it cannot efficiently handle the motion planning problem with discrete and continuous design variables.

TCS is another challenging problem for UAVs, since they are usually required to track predetermined trajectories through certain intermediate and final target points in the three-dimensional (3D) space. This requirement has led to some articles in the literature dedicated to flight path control of UAVs.10,11 Two different approaches can be distinguished in the design of these TCSs. In the most popular approach, the guidance and control laws are separated. In this approach, a given reference trajectory is converted, by the guidance laws, to velocity and attitude commands for the actual flight controller that in turn generates the actuator command signals.12–14 The other design approach integrates the guidance and control laws into one system, to achieve better stability and guaranteed improved performance. Kaminer et al.15 have utilized an integrated guidance and control approach to trajectory tracking where the trimmed flight conditions along the reference trajectory are the command input to the tracking controllers. In the study of Singh et al.,16 a combination of sliding mode control and adaptive control has been used for flight path control of an F/A-18 model.

The design of a TCS is a complicated problem since the system to be controlled is of a high relative degree of freedom (DOF). This could potentially present difficulties for a standard backstepping design since the derivatives of the intermediate control variables have to be analytically calculated in each design step. Calculating the derivatives of the intermediate control variables in each design step leads to a rapid ‘explosion of terms’. Moreover, in standard backstepping and most feedback linearization designs, the contribution of the control surface deflections to the aerodynamic forces cannot be taken into account. For these reasons, in the study of Sonneveldt et al.17 utilizing the command filters,18 a constrained adaptive control system has been designed to track the input commands of velocity, angle of attack, side slip angle, and the roll angle. This approach has been extended in the study of Sonnveldt et al.19 to design a TCS for a nonlinear high-fidelity F-16 model in 3D space. Implementing the command filters, the derivatives of the intermediate controls are simply calculated. Furthermore, these filters can be used to enforce magnitude and rate limits on the states and input variables.

Due to MA capabilities, this study is also based on this approach, while, for the first time, the 6DOF model dynamic, performance as well as the dynamic constraints of the intended UAV are taken into account. In this way, a trim–maneuver library including the TSs and their corresponding transition maneuver trajectories is obtained and stored in an offline fashion. The transition maneuvers of the library are generated using a constrained backstepping control system design approach that allows for a smooth trajectory between the TSs. Utilizing this nonlinear control methodology causes all dynamic and performance constraints of the UAV to be considered in the motion planning process and the resulting trajectories become more realistic and thus feasible. By organizing the trim–maneuver library, the motion planning is converted into a hybrid optimization problem with discrete and continuous design variables. In this regard, the basic particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is enhanced to handle the resulting hybrid optimization problem of motion planning. In addition, by utilizing a nonlinear control system design approach for maneuver generation, via adding a trajectory control loop, a TCS with four feedback loops is developed. Implementing a similar nonlinear control approach for both maneuver generation and TCS provides a satisfactory consistency for the integrated problem of motion planning and trajectory control. The robustness of the TCS against to environmental disturbances is also investigated. The integrated approach flow chart is drawn in Figure 1. Evaluating the integrated approach, through different scenarios, has revealed a satisfactory performance. Figure 1.
Integrated approach flow chart.

The arrangement of this article is as follows. First, the motion planning problem is described. Organization of trim–maneuver library and schemes which are used to form the trim and maneuver trajectories are presented in ‘Development of the trim–maneuver library’ section. Thereafter, ‘Solving the motion planning problem’ section is devoted to the PSO algorithm for motion planning. The nonlinear TCS is described in ‘TCS design’ section. In ‘Simulated scenarios’ section, different scenarios are simulated and the efficiency of algorithm is evaluated. Conclusions are drawn and presented in the last section.

sec.title: Motion planning problem
sec.p: The motion planning problem (Figure 1) consists of four parts: formulation of the system dynamics, specification of internal and external constraints, and defining the cost function. The system dynamic and internal constraints are utilized to form the trim–maneuver library. External constraints include terrain and threats. The cost function defines the strategy according to which the mission must to be performed.

sec.title: System dynamics
sec.p:
The selected dynamic system is that of a fixed-wing UAV with four conventional controls including the elevator, aileron, rudder, and the throttle setting. Some typical characteristics of the selected UAV are listed in Table 1. The nonlinear 6DOF governing equations of motion, assuming a flat Earth, are given below19 (1)g[V·χ·γ·g]=g[g(Tcos(β)cos(α)-Dcos(β)+Ysin(β)-mgsin(γ)mg)g(Dsin(β)cos(μ)+Ycos(μ)cos(β)+Lsin(μ) +Tg(sin(μ)sin(α)-cos(μ)sin(β)cos(α)g)mVcos(γ)g)g(-Dsin(β)sin(μ)-Ysin(μ)cos(β)+Lcos(μ) +Tg(cos(μ)sin(α)+sin(μ)sin(β)cos(α)g)-mgcos(γ)mVg)g] (2)g[α·β·g]=g[q-tan(β)g(cos(α)p+sin(α)rg) +-L+mgcos(γ)cos(μ)-Tsin(α)mVcos(β) ×sin(α)p-cos(α)r +g(mgcos(γ)sin(μ)+Ycos(β)+Dsin(β) -Tsin(β)cos(α)mVg)g] (3)μ·=cos(α)p+sin(α)rcos(β)+g(-mgcos(γ)cos(μ)tan(β)+L(tan(γ)sin(μ)+tan(β))+Dsin(β)tan(γ)cos(μ)mVg)+g(Ytan(γ)cos(μ)cos(β)+Tsin(α)(tan(γ)sin(μ) +tan(β))-Tcos(α)tan(γ)cos(μ)sin(β)mVg) (4)Vg(Sj≥Sig)=heightg(Si∩Sjg) =g{1,ifmj≥mi0,ifli≥ujli-ujg(mj-uig)-g(mi-lig),otherwiseg.}. (5)bfg[x·y·h·g]=g[Vcos(γ)cos(χ)Vcos(γ)sin(χ)Vsin(γ)g]g[x·y·h·g]=g[V cos(γ)cos(χ)V cos(γ)sin(χ)V sin(γ)g] Table 1.
Typical characteristics of the selected UAV.
Mass, m (kg) 80
Wing area, S (m2) 0.9
Wing span, b (m) 2.12
Velocity range, V (m/s) [75, 115]
Side slip angle range, β (°) [−10, 10]
Angle of attack range, α (°) [−8, 14]
Body axis angular rates range, p, q, r (°/s) [−45, 45]
Elevator angle deflection range, δE (°) [−20, 10]
Aileron angle deflection range, δA (°) [−15, 15]
Rudder angle deflection range, δR (°) [−20, 20]
Throttle setting allowable range, δT [0, 1]

sec.title: Internal constraints
sec.p: A set of internal constraints are obtained based on the performance, stability, and simulation analysis of the vehicle under study. Examples of some key constraints are the velocity boundaries, the linear ranges of the angle of attack and the sideslip angle, angular rates limits, elevator, aileron, rudder deflection limits, as well as the throttle position. Table 1 tabulates some of these limitations observed in motion planning problem.

sec.title: External constraints
sec.p: In general, external constraints include the set of limitations that are dictated by the flight environment, in this case terrain obstacles and threat areas.

sec.title: 3D terrain height modeling
sec.p: The following virtual mathematical function is utilized to represent the terrain height (6)elev(x,y)=a0+a1sin(a2+y)+a3sin(x) +a4cos(a5x2+y2) +a6cos(y)+a7sin(a7x2+y2) +a8cos(y)

The operating area is assumed to be limited: 0≤x≤40,000(m) and 0≤y≤40,00 0(m). By proper adjustment of the constant parameters in the terrain equation, a typical profile shown in Figure 2 is attained. Figure 2.
3D view of the virtual terrain model.
Hitting the terrain will result in a failed mission. Thus, to avoid that, a penalty function, Jterrain, is formulated as (7)Jterrain=g{2πσ1expg((h-elev-m1)22σ12g) h≤elev+clrnc0 h>elev+clrncg.

Equation (7) represents an inversed normal distribution function with the mean value m1 and the standard deviation σ1. The clearance altitude, clrnc, is a user-defined altitude representing a measure of a safe altitude at which the vehicle flies above the ground surface. The variable h is the vehicle flying altitude and elev the elevation altitude calculated according to equation (6). As described in equation (7), as soon as the vehicle enters the hazardous zone, the cost exponentially increases. The hazardous zone is defined as the area for which the altitudes are less than elevation height plus a specified clearance altitude. The values selected for the above parameters are addressed in Table 2. Table 2.
Parameters of terrain and threat models.
Parameter Value
Re 2500 (m)
Clrnc 500 (m)
σ1 60
m1 500
Pt 1e10

sec.title: Modeling of threats
sec.p: As it is desired to guide the vehicle away from the threats, a new model for the threatening space is developed here. For this purpose, a vector Pthreat=[xtheat,ythreat,hthreat]T is assigned to the center of each threat. The threats are assumed to be deterministic in nature with known positions. An effective destruction range, Re, is considered for the threats. If the vehicle enters the effective destruction range, it will be penalized by pt that is a pre-specified constant (8)Jthreat=g{ptIfPX<Re0IfPX≥Reg. where PX is the distance between the vehicle’s position vector, [x,y]T, and the threat center (9)PX=(xthreat-x)2+(ythreat-y)2
The threat model parameters, for this study, are given in Table 2.

sec.title: Cost function
sec.p: Two composite types of cost functions are considered. In order to reach the target point in minimum time, the first cost function is set to minimize the total flight time along with deviation to the target point (10)J1=k1(xF-xT)2+(yF-yT)2 +∑i=1n(tTi+tMi,i+1+tTi+1) where [xF,yF]T and [xT,yT]T are the final positions of the planned trajectory and the target, respectively. Here, k1 is a weighting parameter that is set to 100, for this study. Parameters tTi and tMi,i+1 are the steady segment time spans and the time span required for the transition maneuver from TS − i to TS − i + 1, respectively. Also, n is the number of TSs used in the motion planning algorithm to form the trajectory from the start to the target position.

UAVs usually fly at low altitudes and inside the valleys to increase the surveillance capability and to remain undetected by threats. Thus, the second composite cost function is set to minimize the altitude and the minimum distance to the target (11)J1=k1(xF-xT)2+(yF-yT)2+k2∑i=1mhi
The parameter m denotes the number of check points at which the trajectory altitude is checked. Parameters k1 and k2 are weighting constants, set to 100 and 0.01, respectively.
Adding the external constraints of the terrain and threats to the cost functions defined above makes up the total cost function (12)J=min(J1+Jterrain+Jthreat)

sec.title: Development of the trim–maneuver library
sec.p: To form the basis of the motion planning problem, a set of trim and maneuver trajectories are initially determined based on the performance and dynamic capabilities of the UAV under study. These offline generated trajectories can be selected through the operational flight envelope and will construct the so-called trim–maneuver library. The trim–maneuver library includes the TS characteristics (velocity, altitude, turn rate, and rate of climb) as well as feasible maneuver trajectories between any two pairs of trim trajectories. Maneuver characteristics include the 3D trajectory of maneuvers and their corresponding time spans. The trim trajectory time span is not specified in the library and is determined by the motion planning algorithm as described in ‘Solving the motion planning problem’ section.

Three conventional TS flights are used in this research: steady wings level, steady turn, and constant rate of climb/descend.20 By assessing the operational flight envelope, 45 different TSs are selected. These states are compatible with the possible flight conditions given in Table 3. Of course, in selecting these points, the trimmability is also considered. In other words, the vehicle could be trimmed with regards to the internal constraints given in Table 1. The required TS parameters or unknowns are in turn determined using a new constrained heuristic approach21,22 also developed by the authors. An index is assigned to each TS in the library. For example, TS-1 is characterized by V=75(m/s), h·=0, and ψ·=0. Table 3.
Selected flight conditions for the 45 TSs.
Altitude, h(m) 2000
Velocity, V(m/s) 75, 85, 95, 105, 115
Altitude rate, h·(m/s) −6, −3, 0, 5, 10
Heading angle rate, ψ·(∘/s) −10, −5, 0, 5, 10

In this study, to establish a transition network between the existing 45 TSs, a total number of 398 maneuver trajectories are determined and stored in the library. The following transitional strategies are utilized to derive the maneuver trajectories.
Maneuver between different steady wings level TSs (to increase or decrease the UAV velocity in steady flight).
Maneuver between different constant rate of climb TSs (with identical flight velocities).
Maneuver from a TS with higher velocity and smaller rate of climb to a TS with lower velocity and bigger rate of climb.
Maneuver from a TS with lower velocity and bigger rate of climb to a TS with higher velocity and smaller rate of climb.
Maneuver between different steady turn TSs (with identical flight velocities).

A nonlinear control design approach, described in ‘TCS design’ section, is utilized for the design of maneuver trajectories. This approach not only rapidly generates smooth translational maneuvers but also considers all the dynamic and performance characteristics (internal dynamic constraints) of the UAV. For generating the maneuver trajectories, only three loops of the TCS, ‘TCS design’ section, are utilized. Therefore, its input command vector includes the desired values of velocity (V), heading angle (χ), flight path angle (γ), and their corresponding rates.

sec.title: Solving the motion planning problem
sec.p:
After constructing the trim–maneuver library in an offline fashion, outlined in ‘Development of the trim–maneuver library’ section, the proposed algorithm to solve the motion planning problem is introduced. In this regard, it is important to note the following points.
The vehicle starts its mission from a starting point at a predefined TS and time span. During the flight, it can select other TSs within the trim–maneuver library and use maneuver trajectories with predetermined time spans that are already computed and stored in the library. Therefore, the motion planning involves optimal selection of a sequence of TSs and their corresponding time spans. Once the TSs are determined, the maneuver trajectory would also be automatically specified from the trim–maneuver library.
Our problem is regarded as a hybrid optimization problem, because the design variables include both the index number of TSs (discrete variables) and the flight time of those trim trajectories (continuous variables).
Among the existing heuristic optimization algorithms, PSO is selected due to its inherent applicability to continuous search spaces, while it can be simply empowered to handle discrete ones, too.
The PSO algorithm and its implementation to motion planning are discussed in the following section.

sec.title: Implementing PSO to motion planning problem
sec.p: The PSO algorithm is a population-based heuristic global optimization methodology first introduced by Kennedy and Eberhart23 in 1995. Its basic idea was based on the simulation of simplified animal social behaviors such as fish schooling and bird flocking. In basic PSO,24 the vectors xi(t) and vi(t) denote the position and the velocity of particle i in the search space at time/iteration t. The position at iteration (t + 1) is updated in the current movement by (13)xi(t+1)=xi(t)+vi(t)

The velocity vector reflects both the experimental knowledge of a particle and the socially exchanged information from the particle’s neighborhood. The velocity vector of particle i at iteration t+1 is calculated as (14)vi(t+1)=ωvi(t)+c1r1(yi(t)-xi(t)) +c2r2(y∧(t)-xi(t)) where c1 and c2 are the constant parameters, r1 and r2 the random numbers between [0,1], ω the inertia weight that controls the exploration/exploitation capabilities of the swarm, yi(t) the personal best position of particle i from initialization to iteration t, and y∧(t) the best position found by the neighbors at iteration t.

The following modifications are implemented on the basic PSO to increase its exploration/exploitation capabilities and also empower it to handle the motion planning problem.
In PSO, the flow of information through the swarm depends on the social structure. This feature is realized through the social term of equation (14). There are various neighborhood structures like star, ring, wheel, and Von Neumann.24 The singly linked ring structure has risen from analyzing the ring neighborhood as a double-linked ring. In a ring structure, there is a mutual attraction between consecutive particles, forming overlapped clusters. It has also a slow convergence rate. A topology of singly linked ring is also proposed.22,25 This topology keeps two neighbors for each particle, but breaks the mutual attraction between neighbors. In this way, the information is transmitted faster through the whole swarm than in the original ring topology. Therefore, the singly linked ring keeps the exploration at the search space, and increases the exploitation of the best solutions. In this study, the singly linked ring structure is used.
Randomly changing inertia weight ensures a good mix of focus on both exploration and exploitation characteristics.22 Therefore, the inertia weight is randomly selected, so that
(15) ω=rand(0,1)

Here, vi(t+1,j) indicates the velocity of ith particle at (t + 1)th iteration and jth dimension of the search space; vmax is the maximum velocity in each dimension of the search space. Thus, if any component of the velocity vector exceeds this range, it will be reinitialized to a random number within the above allowable range. In this strategy, by randomizing the velocity of saturated particles, the direction of the velocity vector will be changed and in this way, it can also improve the exploration capability. In addition, any component of the position vector which violates its allowable range will be reinitialized to a new random value.
As half of the design variables are discrete values, PSO is empowered to handle them as well. In this regard, a simple strategy is used;26 when the position update process is done, the elements of position vector corresponding to discrete variables are rounded to the nearest valid discrete integers. Therefore, for discrete state variables, the representation of position and velocity vectors remain the same as for the continuous ones and so do the velocity and position update equations.
The optimization design vector, W=[T1,T2,…,TL/2,t1,t2,…,tL/2]T, has a length of L; the first L/2 design variables are for the sequence of TSs and the next L/2 design variables are the time spans of the TSs to be selected by the motion planning algorithm. The length of the design vector in the following case studies is presented in Table 5. However, if the UAV reaches the target point by less TSs, the remaining design variables will not be taken into account.
At the initialization of the algorithm, an initial TS is chosen by the user together with a fixed selected time picked up by the algorithm as the initial flight condition. The design vector does not involve this initial TS and only uses its information to proceed with optimization scheme. In other words, a feasible TS is randomly picked up from the library for its first component T1 in accordance to the selection strategy described in ‘Development of the trim–maneuver library’ section. The other components are also chosen in a similar fashion. The continuous components of the position vector, t1,t2,…,tL/2, will be chosen as random numbers uniformly distributed between (0, 8] s. A fixed number of particles, Np, are selected as the population size and the initial velocity vector components are randomly selected within [-vmax,vmax], at the initialization step.

The motion planning algorithm pseudo-code is presented in Table 4. The algorithm stops after a predetermined number of iterations (Nitr, max). The proposed motion planning algorithm has six control parameters to set. These include: the number of particles (Np), the acceleration coefficients (c1,c2), maximum allowable velocity for each component of the velocity vector (vmax), the design vector length (L), and the maximum number of iterations (Nitr, max) as the stopping criteria. The authors have taken an iterative trial-and-error process to tune these parameters. In this regard, different scenarios are solved with different parameter settings, in an iterative manner, and the results are continually compared to obtain an admissible setting. The final tuned values are listed in Table 5. Table 4.
Pseudo-code for the proposed motion planning algorithm.
//Initialization
Set the parameters of the algorithm: NP,c1,c2,vmax,L and Nitr, max
Select an initial TS with a random time span to start the mission,
Generate NP random particles with the length L (1st L/2 are feasible TSs and the 2nd L/2 are TSs time spans) and an initial random velocity,
Calculate the fitness of all particles
//Main loop
While Stopping criteria (max. number of iterations)
//Update particle positions
For all particles
Calculate the personal best and local best position and fitness,
Update particle positions according to equations (13) and (14),
Utilize equation (16) for the velocity vector,
If any component of the position vector is out of range re-randomize it,
Utilize the strategy, described in ‘Implementing PSO to motion planning problem’ section, for discrete components of the position vector,
End for
End while
Table 5.
Parameters of the proposed PSO algorithm.
Parameter Value
c1 2
c2 1
vmax 8
Np 50
L 100
Nitr, max 10,000

sec.title: TCS design
sec.p: As previously mentioned in ‘Introduction’ section, a nonlinear control system design approach is utilized to track the trajectories determined by the motion planning algorithm. An advantage of the proposed methodology is that it improves the online tracking process of the TCS since it uses the control system design approach similar to that of the maneuver generation. In this approach, command filters18,19 are utilized to calculate the derivatives of the intermediate controls. The command filters also keep the control signals within their mechanical constraints and operating limits. In addition, the contribution of the control surfaces in aerodynamic forces could be taken into account.

The available controls are the conventional control surface deflections δE,δA, and δR as well as the engine throttle setting δT. Assuming no uncertainty in the dynamic model, the TCS is designed by implementing the following four control loops.

sec.title: Trajectory control loop
sec.p: A high-level control system is designed that tracks a smooth, prescribed trajectory Yref=[xref,yref,zref]T with position states X0=[x,y,z]T. It is assumed that the reference trajectory satisfies (17)x·ref=Vrefcos(χref)y·ref=Vrefsin(χref) In this loop, the tracking control problem is transformed into a regulation problem, as follows (18)Z·0=g[z01z02z03g]=g[cos(χ)sin(χ)0-sin(χ)cos(χ)00 001g](X0-Yref) Differentiating equation (18) gives (19)Z·0=g[V+z02χ·-Vrefcos(χ-χref)-z01χ·+Vrefsin(χ-χref)z·ref-Vsin(γ)g]

The objective is to control the position errors, Z0, through virtual controls of the heading angle (χ), flight path angle (γ), and the velocity (V). Therefore, the virtual controls are selected as (20)Vdes=Vrefcos(χ-χref)-c01z01γdes=asing(c03z03-z·refVg),-π/2<γ<π/2χdes=atang(y·refx·refg) where c01,c03>0 are the control system gains. The actual, implementable virtual control signals, as well as their derivatives are obtained by filtering the virtual signals through their corresponding second-order low-pass command filters. The block diagram of the command filter for the typical signal xc0 is shown in Figure 3. The command filter outputs are the filtered signal xc and its derivative x·c. As shown in Figure 3, the command filters can be used to enforce magnitude and rate limits on the states as well. Figure 3.
The block diagram of command filter.

sec.title: Flight path angle and velocity control loop
sec.p: The aerodynamic forces also depend on the control surface deflections U=[δE,δA,δR]T. These forces are quite small, since the surfaces are primarily moment generators. However, since the current control surface deflections are available from the command filters, they are taken into account in the control design. Assuming X1=[V,χ,γ]T and X2=[μ,α,β]T, equation (1) can be presented as (21)X·1=A1F1(X,U)+B1G1(X,U,X2)+H1(X) where (22)F1=g[LYDg] (23)G1=g[Tg(L+Tsin(α)g)sin(μ)g(L+Tsin(α)g)cos(μ)g]

The objective of this loop is to steer V, γ, and χ to their desired values as determined in the previous section. The virtual controls in this step are α, μ, and δT. Therefore, the tracking errors are defined as (24)Z1=g[z11z12z13g]=X1-X1,des To regulate Z1 and z02 to zero, the following equation needs to be satisfied19 (25)B1G1(X,U,X2)=g[-c11z11-Vrefg(c02z02+c12sin(z12)g)-c13z13g] -A1F1-H1+X·1,des where c02,c11,c12,c13>0 are control gains. The right-hand side of equation (25) is entirely known, so that the left-hand side can be determined in order to extract the desired values of αdes and μdes. The following new variables are defined as (26)k1=g(L0+Lαα+Tsin(α)g)sin(μ)k2=g(L0+Lαα+Tsin(α)g)cos(μ) where Lα=0.5ρV2SCLαα and L0=L-Lα. The desired signals [Tdes,k1,k2]T can be calculated as (27)B1g[Tdesk1k2g]=g[-c11z11-Vrefg(c02z02+c12sin(z12)g)-c13z13g] -A1F1-H1+X·1,des Simplifying the above equation, the virtual control signals can be found as (28)αdes=g(k12+k22-L0-Tsin(α)g)/Lα and (29)μdes=g{atang(k2/k1g)ifk1>0atang(k2/k1g)+πifk1<0 and k2≥0atang(k2/k1g)-πifk1<0 and k2<0π/2ifk1=0 and k2>0-π/2ifk1=0 and k2<0g.

Filtering the virtual signals to account for magnitude, rate, and bandwidth limits will give the implementable virtual controls and their derivatives. The sideslip angle command was already defined as βdes=0; thus, X2,des=[μdes,αdes,βdes]T and its derivative are completely defined.

sec.title: Aerodynamic angle control loop
sec.p: The virtual control vector includes the angular rates in this loop, X3=[p,q,r]T. Equations (2) and (3) can be formulated as (30)X·2=A2F1(X,U)+B2(X)X3+H2(X) and the tracking error vector is defined as (31)Z2=X2-X2,des Therefore, the virtual feedback control X3,des is (32)B2X3,des=-C2Z2-A2F1-H2+X·2,des where C2=diag(c21,c22,c23)>0. The implementable virtual control vector, for the next loop, and its derivative are again obtained by filtering the virtual control signal X3,des with its command filters.

sec.title: Angular rates control loop
sec.p: The control inputs for this loop are the control surface deflections U=[δE,δA,δR]T. Equation (4) can be written as (33)X·3=A3g(F3(X,U)+B3(X)Ug)+H3(X) The control objective, in this loop, is to track the reference signal X3,des=[pdes,qdes,rdes]T with the angular rates X=[p,q,r]T. Defining the tracking errors Z3=X3-X3,des and taking the derivatives result in (34)Z·3=A3g(F3(X,U)+B3(X)Ug)+H3(X)-X3,des

In order to stabilize the system of equation (34), the desired control U can be stated as19 (35)A3B3U=-C3Z3-A3F3-H3+X·3,des where C3=diag(c31,c32,c33)>0. The resulting control surface deflections are also passed through their corresponding designed command filter, before implementing them in the plant model. The block diagram of the designed TCS is shown in Figure 4. The blocks entitled as ‘F’, in this figure, are indications for the designed command filters. Figure 4.
The block diagram of TCS.

The parameters of the command filters are set according to the UAV performance and dynamic capabilities and the control system gains as reported in Table 6. Table 6.
Parameters of the TCS.
Parameter Value Parameter Value Parameter Value Parameter Value
c01 0.0001 c11 1 c21 0.35 c31 40
c02 0.0001 c12 0.1 c22 3 c32 40
c03 0.0001 c13 0.6 c23 10 c33 40

sec.title: Simulated scenarios
sec.p: Four routines are developed in the MATLAB and SIMULINK environment for derivation of the TS conditions, maneuver generation, solution of the motion planning algorithm, and the TCS. The routines run on a PC with a 2.0 GHz CPU and 1.0 GB of RAM. Each run of the constrained heuristic optimization approach utilized for TS derivation converges in less than 2 m. Each run of the motion planning algorithm with 10,000 iterations takes about 6 h. Also, as stated before, 6DOF equations of motions are utilized for all phases of motion planning and TCS design. The aerodynamic model of the vehicles is a function of the Mach number and angle of attack. The engine thrust is also modeled as a function of the static thrust and the flight altitude. The capability of the proposed integrated approach is tested by the following case studies. The terrain model of ‘3D terrain height modeling’ section and two types of cost functions described in ‘Cost function’ section are utilized. For all scenarios, the trajectory starts from [x0,y0,h0]=[5000,40,000,elev(x0,y0)+clrnc] and ends at the target point [xF,yF,hF]=[35,000,15,000,elev(xF,yF)+clrnc].

sec.title: Scenario 1: Minimum time trajectory without threats
sec.p:
In this scenario, the only external constraint is the terrain and there is no threat in the scenery. Therefore, Jthreat term of equation (12) is neglected and J1 term of this equation corresponds to equation (10). Both two-dimensional (2D) and 3D trajectories of motion planning and TCS are sketched in Figures 5 and 6. The planning algorithm has found a nearly straight line trajectory as the minimum time trajectory and the control system has efficiently followed it. This is indicative of the good implement ability of the trajectories found by the proposed planning algorithm as well. Figure 5.
Minimum time scenario without threat: control system and motion planning trajectories in the x–y plane.
Figure 6.
Minimum time scenario without threat: 3D trajectories of the control system and motion planning.

sec.title: Scenario 2: Minimum altitude trajectory without threats
sec.p:
Similar to the previous case, there is no threat zone in this scenario. The cost function includes the minimum altitude and the minimum distance to the target, equation (11). The motion planning optimal trajectory is compared with that of TCS in Figures 7 and 8. It can be seen that the UAV flies above the low-altitude terrain elevations and the control system has been able to efficiently track the commanded trajectories. Figure 7.
Minimum altitude scenario without threat: control system and motion planning trajectories in the x–y plane.
Figure 8.
Minimum altitude scenario without threat: 3D trajectories of the control system and motion planning.

sec.title: Scenario 3: Minimum time trajectory with threats
sec.p: In this scenario, in addition to the terrain, two threats with the following coordinates are also added to the scenery [xthreat,1,ythreat,1,hthreat,1] =[18,000,33,000,elev(xthreat,1,ythreat,1)] [xthreat,2,ythreat,2,hthreat,2] =[28,000,2 5,000,elev(xthreat,2,ythreat,2)]

The cost function is taken as the minimum time and the minimum distance to the target, equation (10). Figures 9 and 10 show the 2D and 3D trajectories resulting from both motion planning and the TCS. By comparing this scenario with ‘Scenario 1: Minimum time trajectory without threats’ section, it can be seen that the trajectory deviates from a straight line and avoids the threats. Figure 9.
Minimum time scenario with two threats: Control system and motion planning trajectories in the x–y plane.
Figure 10.
Minimum time scenario with two threats: 3D trajectories of the control system and motion planning.

sec.title: Scenario 4: Minimum altitude trajectory with threats
sec.p:
Again, the cost function is the minimum altitude and the minimum distance to the target. In addition, the scenery has two threats of scenario 3. The motion planning and TCS trajectories are sketched in Figures 11 and 12. The resulting trajectories not only avoid the threat zones but also pass the low-altitude terrain elevations. Figure 11.
Minimum altitude scenario with two threats: control system and motion planning trajectories in the x–y plane.
Figure 12.
Minimum altitude scenario with two threats: 3D trajectories of the control system and motion planning.

Some other results of the four scenarios, studied above, are summarized in Table 7 including the total mission flight time and the miss distance. Scenario 1, which is a minimum time mission, lasts for 350.79 s. Scenario 2 has a flight time of 578.35 s. The total flight time of scenario 3 is the minimum time but in the presence of threats it is 490.21 s. And finally, the fourth scenario has a flight time of 493.96 s. An important desired aspect of the motion planning approach is to reach the target point with an acceptable tolerance. Therefore, the miss distance of the trajectory from the target point is also presented in Table 7. It is clear that in all the four scenarios, the miss distance is small and acceptable. Again, this shows the ability of the proposed algorithm that guides the vehicle toward the target, in the presence of terrain and threat obstacles. Table 7.
Results for studied scenarios.
Scenario Total time (s) Miss distance (m)
1 350.79 195
2 578.35 21
3 490.21 31
4 493.96 62

sec.title: Motion planning algorithm validation
sec.p:
In order to validate the proposed motion planning algorithm and the level of optimality achieved by its resulting trajectories, a comparison study is also performed. For this purpose, an optimal control formulation of the problem is implemented.27 For simplicity, only the kinematics equations are used. The velocity is assumed to be constant (V=100m/s) and the vehicle is commanded to follow a terrain elevation profile. A hybrid cost function is taken as (36)J=∫t0tfg(1-k+k(elev(x,y)+clrncg)dt where k is a regulating parameter in the interval [0,1]. For instance, k = 0 denotes a time optimal objective, and k = 1 reflects a minimum altitude objective. Here, k is set to 0 and 1 to be more compatible with the objective functions of the minimum time (‘Scenario 1: Minimum time trajectory without threats’ section) and minimum altitude (‘Scenario 2: Minimum attitude trajectory without threats’ section) scenarios of the motion planning problem. The resulting trajectories of these cases are compared with the PSO motion planning as sketched in Figures 13 and 14. As these figures show, for the case of minimum time cost function, the motion planning trajectory is very close to the optimal control trajectory in the x–y plane. In the case of minimum altitude objective, both trajectories pass through the low-altitude elevation contours and nearly follow similar trends. This analysis is regarded as a test for optimal production of trajectories by the proposed motion planning algorithm. The superiority of the proposed motion planning algorithm in comparison with the optimal control approach is that it considers all the performance and dynamic capabilities of the vehicle. Therefore, its generated trajectories are more realistic. Figure 13.
Minimum time scenario: motion planning algorithm and optimal control trajectories in x–y plane.
Figure 14.
Minimum altitude scenario: motion planning algorithm and optimal control trajectories in x–y plane.

sec.title: TCS robustness verification
sec.p:
In order to investigate the robustness characteristics of the designed TCS, the UAV is subjected to external disturbances of Dryden turbulence as well as discrete wind gust models28 during the mission of scenario 2. The parameters of both Dryden turbulence and discrete wind gust are presented in Tables 8 and 9. In this case, the resulting linear and angular velocity components are fluctuating, as shown in Figure 15. However, the resulting trajectory in the presence of the disturbances has not dramatically changed, as shown in Figure 16. The reason, of course, is due to the second-order low-pass command filters utilized. Thus, one can conclude that the designed TCS is potentially robust against the external disturbances. Figure 15.
Comparison of total velocities.
Figure 16.
Comparison of the resulting trajectories.
Table 8.
Dryden wind turbulence model.
Wind speed at 6 (m) altitude (m/s) 15
Wind direction at 6 (m) altitude 0
Probability of exceedance of high altitude intensity 1e − 5
Scale length at medium/high altitude (m) 533.4
Band limited noise sample time (s) 0.1
Noise speeds [ug, vg, wg, pg] [23,341, 23,342, 23,343, 23,344]
Table 9.
Discrete wind gust model ‘1-cos’ form.
Gust start time (s) 0
Gust length [dx, dy, dz] (m) [120, 120, 80]
Gust amplitude [ug, vg, wg] (m/s) [3.5, 3.5, 3]

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The problem of integrated motion planning and TCS is investigated. The integrated approach helps to generate feasible trajectories in presence of terrain and scenery threats, while the nonlinear trajectory control approach guarantees smooth and efficient tracking capability. The MA is taken with vehicle nonlinear 6DOF dynamics and performance constraints to acquire a library of feasible trim and maneuver trajectories. By developing proper tools and forming the trim–maneuver library, the complicated motion planning problem is converted into a hybrid optimization problem and a special PSO algorithm is empowered to generate feasible trajectories. Utilizing a nonlinear control system design approach, both to generate the maneuver trajectories of the motion planning algorithm, as well as providing it for tracking capability for the offline generated trajectories are consistent and considered as important contributions of this study. The proposed integrated scheme not only yields feasible trajectories but also allows for efficiently tracking of the resulting trajectories. Different cost functions, in addition to the terrain and threats, are examined. Simulation results considered over various scenarios have produced optimal trajectories well tracked by the designed TCS.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This Research was performed as part of a PhD program requirements with no special organizational funding.
